[[File:Jordan lead codex.jpg|thumb|alt=A weathered-looking ring-bound book laid open.|One of the lead codices]]
The '''Jordan Lead Codices''', (or the '''Jordanian Codices'''), are a collection of [[codex|codices]] allegedly found in a cave in Jordan and first publicized in March 2011. A number of scholars and a November 2012 regional [[BBC News]] investigation have pronounced them fakes. In December 2016, a radioactivity test performed at the University of Surrey's Ion Beam Centre confirmed the old age of the lead used, but not the inscriptions. As of 2017, both the Israeli antiquities authority and the Jordanian archaeological department regard them as forgeries.
==Initial press reports and comments== On 3 March 2011 ''[[The Jewish Chronicle]]'' ran an interview with a metallurgist named Robert Feather, who it stated was trying to authenticate a collection of 20 metal books which could be linked to the [[Kabbalah]]. These items were in the possession of an Israeli [[Bedouin]] farmer named Hassan Saeda, who claimed that they had been found by his great-grandfather in a cave a century ago. It added that a piece of leather from the find had already been carbon dated to 2,000 years ago. The article reported that the [[Israel Antiquities Authority]] (IAA) considered them inauthentic and worthless, saying the books are a "mixture of incompatible periods and styles without any connection or logic. Such forged motifs can be found in their thousands in the antiquities markets of Jordan and elsewhere in the Middle East". It added that Professor [[André Lemaire]], an [[epigraphy|epigrapher]] and director of studies at the [[École pratique des hautes études]], said the inscriptions he has seen make no sense and that it was "a question apparently of sophisticated fakes".<ref name=rocker>{{cite news |first=Simon |last=Rocker |url=http://www.thejc.com/judaism/judaism-features/46028/heavy-metal-secrets-a-mid-east-cave |title=Heavy metal secrets from a Mid-East Cave |work=Jewish Chronicle |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=2 April 2011}}</ref>
On 22 March 2011 David Elkington issued a press release stating that a hoard of ancient books made of lead and copper, together with other artefacts, probably dating from the 1st century AD, had been found in Jordan, and that they might predate the writings of [[Paul the Apostle|St. Paul]] and that "leading academics" believed they might be as important as the [[Dead Sea Scrolls]].<ref name=Elkington>David Elkington, [https://www.scribd.com/doc/51540533/Lead-Plates-Press-Release Secret hoard of ancient sealed books found in Jordan]. Retrieved 2 April 2011. </ref> Elkington also stated that the items were discovered 5 years previously in a cave by a Jordanian Bedouin and smuggled into Israel, where they were at risk of sale on the black market or of destruction.<ref name=Elkington/> The BBC, the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' and other media outlets quickly picked up the story.
Elkington stated that the find consisted of "up to 70 ring-bound books (codices) made of lead and copper. Many of them are sealed on all sides. Scrolls, tablets and other artefacts, including an incense bowl, were also found at the same site. Some of the lead pages are written in a form of archaic Hebrew script with ancient messianic symbols. Some of the writing appears to be in a form of code." In the press release he stated that his team included biblical scholars [[Margaret Barker]] and [[Philip R. Davies]].<ref name=Elkington/>
The [[BBC]] version of the story stated that the codices had been found in a cave in [[Jordan]] sometime between 2005 and 2007.<ref name=pigott> {{cite news |first=Robert |last=Pigott |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12888421 |title=Jordan battles to regain 'priceless' Christian relics |work=[[BBC News]] |date=29 March 2011 |accessdate=6 April 2011}}</ref>
''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' added that metallurgical analysis on the books, and carbon dating on a piece of leather found with the collection, suggested that the books could be about 2,000 years old, although it also questioned whether the find was authentic.<ref name=blomfield>Adrian Blomfield, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/jordan/8414393/Jordan-vows-to-recover-artefacts-as-important-as-Dead-Sea-Scrolls.html "Jordan vows to recover artefacts as important as Dead Sea Scrolls"], Telegraph, 29 March 2011 </ref><ref name=lehmann> Chris Lehmann, [https://news.yahoo.com/s/yblog_thelookout/20110330/ts_yblog_thelookout/could-lead-codices-prove-the-major-discovery-of-christian-history "Could lead codices prove ‘the major discovery of Christian history’?"], Yahoo News, 30 March 2011</ref> Elkington, described as a "scholar of ancient religious archaeology who is heading a British team trying to get the lead books safely into a Jordanian museum", claimed that they could be "the major discovery of Christian history", and the director of the Jordan's Department of Antiquities, Ziad al-Saad, said that the books might have been made by followers of Jesus in the few decades immediately following his crucifixion.<ref name=pigott/>
The BBC article said that the books consist of between 5-15 leaves or plates each, about the size of a credit card, made of lead and copper, and bound together with lead rings on one side. Many of the books are also sealed with rings on the remaining three sides. Elkington reported that "In the upper square [of one of the book covers] we have the seven-branch menorah", and the text is said to be in archaic [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] script ([[Paleo Hebrew]]), and some in "code".<ref name=pigott/>
Davies noted the presence of a cross, tomb, and city of [[Jerusalem]] depicted in the books.<ref name=pigott/>
A news report described Barker as believing that if the artefacts are genuine, they could be Christian texts from as early as 33 AD.<ref name=derby>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-derbyshire-12881931 |title=Derby expert examines 'ancient Christian books' |work=BBC News |date=30 March 2011 |accessdate=6 April 2011}} </ref> A BBC report stated that a line has been translated from the text as "I shall walk uprightly".<ref name=pigott/>
The press release<ref name=Elkington/> and the BBC report on 29 March 2011 indicated that the Jordanian government would make a claim for the ownership of the collection under the [[treasure-trove]] statutes of Jordanian law.
==Further developments== ===2011 updates=== A number of experts urged scepticism until further investigation could be conducted.<ref>Larry Hurtado, [http://larryhurtado.wordpress.com/2011/03/29/more-on-the-lead-codices/ "More on the Lead Codices"], Larry Hurtado's Blog, 29 March 2011.</ref><ref>G. Jeffrey MacDonald, [http://www.csmonitor.com/Science/2011/0331/Could-new-discovery-trump-Dead-Sea-Scrolls-Scholars-intrigued-but-cautious "Could new discovery trump Dead Sea Scrolls? Scholars intrigued but cautious"], The Christian Science Monitor, 31 March 2011</ref><ref>Michael De Groote, [http://www.deseretnews.com/article/700123230/Ancient-metal-plates-found-in-Middle-East.html "Ancient metal plates found in Middle East"], Deseret News, 31 March 2011</ref><ref>April DeConick, [http://forbiddengospels.blogspot.com/2011/03/lead-tablets-come-on.html "Lead Tablets? Come on."], The Forbidden Gospels, 31 March 2011</ref>
On 31 March 2011, a letter was published online by [[Daniel C. Peterson]] which had been written in 2010 by Elkington. The letter was to Oxford academic Peter Thonemann, sending images of a "copper tablet" and asking for information regarding the Greek text inscribed on it. Thonemann replied that the item was a modern forgery, created during the last 50 years in Jordan, because the text copied a truncated tombstone inscription (AD 108/9) from the Archaeological Museum of [[Amman]].<ref>According to Thonemann, the inscription read, "without grief, farewell! Abgar also known as Eision."''TLS'' (8 April 2011), 15.</ref> Thonemann said that he "would stake [his] career" on his belief that the material had been faked.<ref>Daniel Peterson, 1 April 2011. Retrieved 5 April 2011. [http://www.mormondialogue.org/topic/53799-early-christian-books-on-lead-plates/page__p__1208992732#entry1208992732].</ref>[http://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/divinity/rt/staff/jrd4/ Professor Jim Davila] also published Elkington's letter and Thonemann's reply. In his letter to Thonemann in 2010, Elkington said that he had been told that the codices were from Egypt, not that the material was from Jordan as stated in his press release.<ref>Jim Davila, ''Paleojudaica'', [http://paleojudaica.blogspot.com/2011_03_27_archive.html#7454369078247746754 HEBREW-INSCRIBED-METAL-CODICES WATCH: A FAKE]. Retrieved 2 April 2011.</ref>
Also on 2 April 2011, historian [[William J. Hamblin]] called into question the Jesus image on the tablet, stating it looked a great deal like images of Helios also found on ancient coins.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hamblinofjerusalem.wordpress.com/2011/04/02/jordan-metal-plates-2-portrait-of-jesus |last=Hamblin |first=William |title=Jordan Metal Plates 2: Portrait of Jesus? |date=2 April 2011 |access-date=10 December 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110407013411/http://hamblinofjerusalem.wordpress.com/2011/04/02/jordan-metal-plates-2-portrait-of-jesus/ |archive-date=7 April 2011}}</ref>
On 3 April 2011, ''[[The Mail on Sunday]]'' published an interview with Hassan Saeda, whom it described as a Bedouin trucker, aged 37, including extra images from the material and a story of how they came into his possession. The paper made a claim that a face on one plate "could be" the face of Jesus, but gave no authority for it.<ref>{{cite news |first=Nick |last=Pryer |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1372741/Hidden-cave-First-portrait-Jesus-1-70-ancient-books.html |title=Is this the first ever portrait of Jesus? The incredible story of 70 ancient books hidden in a cave for nearly 2,000 years |work=The Mail on Sunday |date=3 April 2011 |accessdate=4 April 2011}}</ref> On the same day the ''[[Sunday Telegraph]]'' published an interview with Elkington.<ref>{{cite news |first=Olga |last=Craig |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/8423689/Could-this-couples-Bible-codices-tell-the-true-story-of-Christs-life.html |title=Could this couple's Bible 'codices' tell the true story of Christ's life? |work=Sunday Telegraph |date=3 April 2011 |accessdate=4 April 2011}}</ref> An article in ''The Daily Telegraph'' on the same day stated that David Elkington was also known as Paul Elkington, and had a book on the codices which literary agent Curtis Brown would be trying to market to publishers at the [[London Book Fair]] on 11 April.<ref>Olga Craig, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/8423689/Could-this-couples-Bible-codices-tell-the-true-story-of-Christs-life.html#dsq-content Could this couple's Bible 'codices' tell the true story of Christ's life?], Daily Telegraph, 3 April 2011. Retrieved 14 April 2011.</ref>
On 4 April 2011, [[Philip R. Davies]] posted a statement on Sheffield's Biblical Studies blog suggesting that, while he recognized that the images were modern, the codices were probably not a hoax nor "forgeries".<ref>{{cite web |last=Davies |first=Philip |title=Philip Davies on Lead Codices |url=http://sheffieldbiblicalstudies.wordpress.com/2011/04/04/philip-davies-on-lead-codices/ |work=Sheffield Biblical Studies blog |date=4 April 2011 |accessdate=4 April 2011}}</ref> On the same day an unconfirmed report appeared, dated to 3 April, on the [[Middle East Media Research Institute|MEMRI]] Web site quoting Ziyad Al-Sa'd, director-general of Jordan's antiquities authority, as saying that the items were found in Jordan and sold on the black market to an "Israeli antiquities dealer". There was no indication of whether Hassan Saeda was meant here.<ref>[http://www.thememriblog.org/blog_personal/en/36219.htm Jordanian Official: Ancient Manuscripts Discovered In Jordan Sold On Black Market To Israel Dealer], 4 April 2011. Retrieved 4 April 2011.</ref> Questions were also raised by Steve Caruso, an Aramaic translator, about the authenticity of the script used on the plates.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Carusu|first1=Steve|title=Finally a Good Look at the “Lead Codices” Script|url=http://aramaicnt.org/2011/04/04/finally-a-good-look-at-the-lead-codices-script/|website=The Aramaic New Testament|accessdate=25 March 2018|date=4 April 2011}}</ref>
[http://www.robert-deutsch.com/ Robert Deutsch] weighed in on 5 April, arguing that the tablets lacked patina and corrosion and, along with others, he noted that all the iconography and script appeared to come directly from coins dating to multiple periods ([[Hellenistic period|Hellenistic]], [[Hasmonean coinage|Hasmonean]], and [[Bar Kokhba revolt|Bar Kokhba]]) in antiquity.<ref>{{cite web|last=Deutsch|first=Robert|title=A Follow up by Robert Deutsch on the ‘Lead Codices’|url=http://zwingliusredivivus.wordpress.com/2011/04/05/a-follow-up-by-robert-deutsch-on-the-lead-codices/|accessdate=5 April 2011}}</ref>
On 6 April 2011 Peter Thonemann repeated his statements about a letter from Elkington in 2010 in ''[[The Times Literary Supplement]]''.<ref>Peter Thonemann, [http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/the_tls/article7173961.ece "The Messiah codex decoded"], Times Literary Supplement, 6 April 2011: "There are various reasons why we bother to fund research in the arts and humanities and this episode could have been one of them."</ref> On 6 April ''[[The Jordan Times]]'' published an article describing the codices as a collection of 2,000-year-old manuscripts.<ref>Taylor Luck, [http://www.jordantimes.com/?news=36138 Authorities confident old Christian manuscript smuggled to Israel, Jordan Times]. Retrieved 13 April 2011</ref> On 6 April Dr. James E. Deitrick suggested that the image on one of the lead plates is a replica of a 3rd-century mosaic portrait dubbed "The Mona Lisa of the Galilee."<ref>James E. Deitrick, [http://deorientation.blogspot.com/2011/04/jesus-mona-lisa-smile-update-better.html Jesus' Mona Lisa Smile: Update, Better Images] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110412164604/http://deorientation.blogspot.com/2011/04/jesus-mona-lisa-smile-update-better.html |date=12 April 2011 }}. Retrieved 12 April 2011.</ref>
On 9 April Prof. [[James R. Davila|Jim Davila]] published the following summary on his PaleoJudaica blog:
:The Greek is lifted nonsensically from an inscription published in 1958. The forger couldn't tell the difference between the Greek letters alpha and lambda. The Hebrew script is taken from the same inscription. The Hebrew text is in "code," i.e., is gibberish. The "Jesus" face is taken from a well-known mosaic. The charioteer is taken from a fake coin. The crocodile has a suspicious resemblance to a plastic toy. This forger was not [[Professor Moriarty]]. This forger was a careless bumbler. That makes it all the more galling how readily the media fell for the scam.<ref>Jim Davila, [http://paleojudaica.blogspot.com/2011_04_03_archive.html#7679019901722870405 Fake Metal Codices Watch], Paleojudaica, 8 April 2011.</ref>
On 11 April the ''[[Daily Express]]'' reported Thonemann's comments together with a response by David Elkington that Thonemann was not a biblical scholar but a Greek scholar.<ref>Roddy Ashworth, [http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/239742/Unholy-row-as-new-expert-calls-ancient-scrolls-fakes- Unholy row as new expert calls ancient scrolls fakes] Retrieved 11 April 2011.</ref> Also on 11 April, [[LiveScience]] reported that the letter forms were a mixture of old [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] and much younger scripts, and that the mixture indicated a modern forgery.<ref>Natalie Wolchover, [http://www.livescience.com/13657-exclusive-early-christian-lead-codices-called-fakes.html Exclusive: Early Christian Lead Codices Now Called Fakes], 11 April 2011, retrieved 12 April 2011</ref>
On 27 April a report appeared on [[Yahoo! News]] via the [[Associated Press]] that the Jordanian police had seized seven metal codices.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110426/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_jordan_antiquities Jordanian police recover 7 ancient manuscripts], 26 April 2011. Retrieved 27 April 2011</ref> Further details appeared in ''The Jordan Times'', with further claims.<ref>Jim Davila, [http://paleojudaica.blogspot.com/2011_04_24_archive.html#3257234323615319033 More on the new Jordanian codices], 29 April 2011.</ref>
In the July 2011 issue of ''[[Palestine Exploration Quarterly]]'', [[Philip R. Davies]] published an editorial surveying some of the information surrounding the tablets, urging caution and the need for further investigation.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Davies|first=Philip|title=Mysterious Books from Jordan|year=2011|journal=Palestine Exploration Quarterly|volume=143|issue=2|pages=79–84|publisher=Maney Publishing|doi=10.1179/003103211X12971861557115|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/maney/peq/2011/00000143/00000002/art00001|accessdate=31 March 2012}}</ref>
===2012 updates=== On 26 November 2012, BBC News conducted a short investigation about the authenticity of the codices. This was conducted as a short 13 minute segment of ''Inside Out West'' (26/11/12) <ref name="youtube.com">[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XylH2Y8n2dM], 26 November 2012.</ref> accompanied by a written BBC News article entitled "Jordan Codices 'expert' David Elkington's claims queried".<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-20492489], 26 November 2012.</ref> The programme initially focused on the codices' authenticity with Peter Thonemann again affirming that "I'm as certain as it is possible to be that this entire body of codices are modern fakes. I would stake my academic reputation on it" adding that "all of the codices that have appeared in the media in the past year or so are products of the same modern workshop — they’ve all sorts of similarities in style, fabric, and content. It seems absolutely clear that every single one of these documents is a modern fake".<ref name="youtube.com"/> A spokesman for the Israeli Antiquities Authority (IAA) noted, "They were shown to experts on the period; all the experts absolutely doubted their authenticity." Author and metals expert Robert Feather was also sceptical.<ref name="youtube.com"/>
The BBC ''[[Inside Out (2002 TV programme)|Inside Out]]'' programme shifted focus onto whether David Elkington was the right person to be testing the authenticity of the codices, analysing the true intentions, history and qualifications of the "self styled" academic. It emerged that David Elkington is not an academic and has "No recognised qualifications in the field" although previously using the title of Professor.<ref name="youtube.com"/> It also emerged that Elkington is "using the codices to raise money to support him in his work"<ref name="youtube.com"/> from supporters including [[Princess Elizabeth of Yugoslavia]] who has donated tens of thousands of pounds to Elkington. It also stated that Elkington plans to release a book and create a film based upon the codices and that "over the years he’s taken thousands of pounds as investment to make a film based on his theories".<ref name="youtube.com"/>
===2015 updates===
In March 2015 the start of the Centre for the Study of the Jordanian Lead Books, a limited not-for-profit company, was announced under the aegis of [[Richard Chartres]], Bishop of London.<ref name="economist2015"/> The board is chaired by [[Margaret Barker]] and includes two politicians, Sir [[Tony Baldry]] and [[Tom Spencer (politician)|Tom Spencer]]. Other people involved include Professor Robert Hayward, of Durham University and Professor Ziad Al Saad as co-chairs of the “evaluation panel” and Professor [[Philip R. Davies|Philip Davies]] of the University of Sheffield, Matthew Hood, Professor Bernhard Lang, Professor Yuri Stoyanov, and Samuel Zinner as other members of the evaluation panel.<ref name="economist2015">{{cite news|title=A chink of light|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/erasmus/2015/03/religious-archaeology|accessdate=28 March 2017|work=The Economist|date=18 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="CT2015">{{cite news|last1=Davies|first1=Margaret|title=Jordan lead books' authenticity to be tested|url=https://www.churchtimes.co.uk/articles/2015/20-march/news/uk/jordan-lead-books-authenticity-to-be-tested|accessdate=26 March 2017|work=Church Times|date=20 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="centre-aboutus">{{cite web|title=About us|url=http://www.leadbookcentre.com/about-us.php|website=The Centre for the Study of the Jordanian Lead Books|accessdate=26 March 2017|language=en}}</ref> The centre disclaims any connection to David Elkington though his wife, Jennifer Elkington was a board member for one day.<ref name="centre-aboutus"/><ref name="companieshouse">{{cite web|title=THE CENTRE FOR THE STUDY OF THE JORDANIAN LEAD BOOKS LIMITED - Officers (free information from Companies House)|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/09705928/officers|website=Companies House|accessdate=28 March 2017|language=en}}</ref>
===2017 updates=== On 9 March 2017, the Jordanian department of antiquities issued a statement criticizing David Elkington's activity in the country after the Ion Beam Centre's results. The department said that the information Elkington was promoting on local media and at local universities was inaccurate and lacked objectivity, and that there was no evidence to support the codices' authenticity. The Jordan Times reported that {{Quote|text=The department described the findings of David Elkington as baseless, stressing that the cave was not found and the pictures he has have nothing to do with the cave that was visited, which indicates that his insistence on the originality of the codices is groundless and not credible. Jamhawi [the antiquities department director] said that modern technology can be used to create confusion since it can use old materials and draw on it to make almost unrecognizable fake antiquities.<ref name="JT2017">{{cite news|title=Antiquities agency chief says Jordan Codices fake|url=http://www.jordantimes.com/news/local/antiquities-agency-chief-says-jordan-codices-fake|accessdate=10 March 2017|language=English|work=Jordan Times|date=9 March 2017}}</ref>}} The Elkingtons still maintain that the codices are credible and are 2000 years old.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://royanews.tv/news/118619/1489065469|title=الآثار تنفي صحة ما يتم تداوله حول 'دساتير الأردن الرصاصية'|language=Arabic|work=[[Ro'ya TV]]|accessdate=9 March 2017|date=9 March 2017}}</ref><ref name="JT2017"/>

[[File:ModernEgypt,_Khedivial_Opera_House,_BAP_25178.jpg|thumb|right|240px|The [[w:Khedivial Opera House|Khedivial Opera House]] in 1869.]] [[File:ModernEgypt, Khedivial Opera House, BAP 25803.jpg|thumb|240px|The Khedivial Opera House.]] The '''Khedivial Opera House''' or '''Royal Opera House''' ({{lang-ar|دار الأوبرا الخديوية }} / [[ALA-LC]]: ''Dār Awbirā al-Khudaywī'') was an opera house in [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]], the oldest opera house in all of Africa. It was inaugurated on 1 November 1869 and burned down on 28 October 1971.
The opera house was built on the orders of the [[Khedive]] [[Isma'il Pasha|Ismail]] to celebrate the opening of the [[Suez Canal]]. The architects [[Pietro Avoscani]] (from [[Livorno]]) and Rossi<!--need first name--> designed the building. It seated approximately 850 people and was made mostly of wood. It was located between the districts of [[Azbakeya]] and Ismailyya<!--Do we have an article on this place?--> in Egypt's capital city.
[[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]]'s opera ''[[Rigoletto]]'' was the first opera performed at the opera house on 1 November 1869. Ismail planned a grander exhibition for his new theatre. After months of delay due to the outbreak of the [[Franco-Prussian War]], Verdi's new opera, ''[[Aida]]'', received its world premiere at the Khedivial Opera House on 24 December 1871.
In the early morning hours of 28 October 1971, the opera house burned to the ground. The all-wooden building was quickly consumed, and only two statues made by [http://www.fineart.gov.eg/eng/cv/cv.asp?IDS=323 Mohamed Hassan] survived.
After the original opera house was destroyed, Cairo was without an opera house for nearly two decades until the opening of the new [[Cairo Opera House]] in 1988.
The site of the Khedivial Opera House has been rebuilt into a multi-story concrete car garage. The square (to the south of Al Ataba metro station) overlooking the building's location, is still called Opera Square (Meidan El Opera)

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=January 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} This article lists individual current and past [[Road protest in the United Kingdom|Road protests in the United Kingdom]] and in Ireland.
==Current protests==
===Bristol [[MetroBus (Bristol)|Metrobus]] [[M32 motorway|M32]] bus only bridge and junction=== On 1 February 2015 the protest group 'Rising Up' occupied land at Stapleton Allotments and Smallholdings, the planned site for a new motorway bus junction as part of the Bristol Metrobus North Fringe to Hengrove Project (NFHP). Building the junction and associated roads will result in a loss of [[Green Belt]] land, loss of long-held allotments (albeit with new laid plots being provided), and loss of smallholdings on some of the best soils in the country. The protesters claim that the junction is unnecessary and that buses could be routed via a suitably modified Junction 1 of the M32 at much less cost and with no loss of valuable growing land.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/feb/02/bristol-bus-protesters-trees-european-green-capital-2015|title=Bristol bus protesters take to the trees|first=Steven|last=Morris|date=2 February 2015|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-31088052 | work=BBC News | title=Bristol tree-top protest against Metrobus scheme | date=2015-02-02}}</ref>
===Central Access Scheme, Kilkenny, Ireland=== [[Kilkenny Central Access Scheme]] (CAS), previously Kilkenny Inner Relief Road Scheme, is sections of new road, improvement of existing roads and junctions, and a new River Nore bridge crossing, with provisions for footpaths and cycle lanes throughout. CAS comprises 4.5 kilometers of single carriageway road that is 7.3 metres wide.
The proposed route dissects the medieval core of the old Irishtown of [[Kilkenny]], one of the most historic quarters of the city.
The campaign group called "Complete [[Kilkenny]] Ring Road as a priority over the CAS" or CKRR is holding demonstrations to gain further support for a call to rethink the CAS and demand to complete the outer ring road around [[Kilkenny]]. Several of Kilkenny’s leading figures in the areas of tourism, heritage and archaeology – as well as local residents – have come out strongly against the imminent demolition of a number of historic buildings and the altering of one of the city’s oldest streetscapes.<ref name=":0" />
===A14 Ellington to Fen Ditton=== {{see also|A14 road (Great Britain)}} The [[Highways Agency]] wishes to increase capacity on the busy section of the [[A14 road (Great Britain)|A14]] between Ellington and Fen Ditton.<ref name=":0">{{cite web |title=Huge concern over demolition of historic city buildings |url=http://www.kilkennypeople.ie/news/kilkenny-news/huge-concern-over-demolition-of-historic-city-buildings-1-5142168 |publisher=Kilkenny People}}</ref> to reduce congestion and improve safety<ref>{{cite web |title = Stage 2 Scheme Assessment Report - Part 1, Volume 1, Part A |url = http://www.highways.gov.uk/roads/projects/6908.aspx |publisher = UK Highways Agency |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080704212627/http://www.highways.gov.uk/roads/projects/6908.aspx |archivedate = 4 July 2008 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
The ''Offords A14 Action Group'' formed to oppose the proposed route (the ''Orange route'') for the scheme, favouring the ''Brown route'' which would have taken the new road further away from their villages.<ref name="cen_20071025">{{cite news |title = Finally, work can begin on A14 upgrades |date = 2007-10-25 |url = http://www2.cambridge-news.co.uk/news/huntingdon/2007/10/25/726d922e-25ff-4825-8d91-c9098e86250b.lpf |publisher = Cambridge Evening News |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080316072920/http://www2.cambridge-news.co.uk/news/huntingdon/2007/10/25/726d922e-25ff-4825-8d91-c9098e86250b.lpf |archivedate = 16 March 2008 |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title = A14 campaigners hit by council's decision |date = 2007-02-26 |url = http://www2.cambridge-news.co.uk/news/huntingdon/2007/02/26/866a128b-498a-40a8-a2f1-8c827f33ecfd.lpf |publisher = Cambridge Evening News |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080316072915/http://www2.cambridge-news.co.uk/news/huntingdon/2007/02/26/866a128b-498a-40a8-a2f1-8c827f33ecfd.lpf |archivedate = 16 March 2008 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> [[Cambridgeshire County Council]] have backed the scheme,<ref name="cen_20071025"/> and there is reported to be widespread support within the local communities for the plans.<ref>{{cite news |title = County unites to demand A14 work |date = 2007-04-07 |url = http://www2.cambridge-news.co.uk/news/region_wide/2007/04/07/c5123573-15d6-4b63-933c-184b171e98e4.lpf |publisher = Cambridge Evening News |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070519043747/http://cambridge-news.co.uk/news/region_wide/2007/04/07/c5123573-15d6-4b63-933c-184b171e98e4.lpf |archivedate = 19 May 2007 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
===A514 Swarkestone Causeway protest=== During 2009 a protest group campaigning for a new causeway at [[Swarkestone]], [[Derbyshire]] was established.<ref>http://www.swarkestonecauseway.webs.com {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104045425/http://swarkestonecauseway.webs.com/ |date=4 January 2014 }}</ref>
===A57/A628 Mottram in Longdendale, Hollingworth and Tintwistle Bypass=== {{main|Longdendale Bypass}} The Highways Agency (HA) have planned to provide a section of bypass (also known as the [[Longdendale Bypass]]) to tackle congestions problems in [[Mottram in Longdendale|Mottram]], [[Hollingworth]], and [[Tintwistle]].<ref>{{cite web |title=A57/A628 Mottram in Longdendale, Hollingworth and Tintwistle Bypass |url=http://www.highways.gov.uk/roads/projects/5515.aspx |publisher=UK Highways Agency |accessdate=2008-01-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026033235/http://www.highways.gov.uk/roads/projects/5515.aspx |archivedate=26 October 2007 |df= }}</ref> and residents of these villages have campaigned for a bypass since the 1970s.<ref name=MEN_green/> Four groups: the ''Save Swallows Wood campaign'', the ''Friends of the Peak District'', the ''Council for the National Parks'', and South Yorkshire group ''WAIT'' oppose the scheme, which will pass through the [[Peak District National Park]], and the [[Swallows Wood]] nature reserve.<ref name=MEN_green>{{cite news |title=Green plea to stop Peak probe |date=2007-03-30 |publisher=Manchester Evening News |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/s/1003/1003222_green_plea_to_stop_peak_probe.html |accessdate=2008-01-17}}</ref> In December 2007 the inquiry was adjourned for the fourth time at the request of the Highways Agency who requested time to adjust their correct their traffic modelling, the inspector commented that it was the fifth iteration of the traffic model since the original announcement in February 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lttonline.co.uk/lttxtraarticle.php?uid=7169|title=Controversial HA bypass inquiry adjourned for the fourth time|date=2008-01-11|work=Local Transport Today|accessdate=2008-01-21}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===Boston Bypass=== {{see also|Boston Bypass Independents}} In May 2007 a [[single-issue]] political party, the ''Independent Bypass Group'', campaigning for a [[Bypass (road)|bypass]] to be built around [[Boston, Lincolnshire|Boston]], [[Lincolnshire]], took control of [[Boston (borough)|Boston Borough Council]], wiping out the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] majority.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bypass group wins race for Boston |date=2007-05-04 |publisher=BBC |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/lincolnshire/6603565.stm |accessdate=2008-01-21 }}</ref>
===Norwich Northern Distributor Road=== {{main|Norwich Northern Distributor Road}} A proposed road scheme to the north of Norwich linking the [[A1067 road]] and [[Norwich International Airport]] to the [[A47 road|A47]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.norfolk.gov.uk/consumption/idcplg?IdcService=SS_GET_PAGE&nodeId=3683 |title=Northern Distributor Road |publisher=Norfolk County Council |accessdate=2008-11-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080917190815/http://www.norfolk.gov.uk/consumption/idcplg?IdcService=SS_GET_PAGE&nodeId=3683 |archivedate=17 September 2008 |df= }}</ref> has attracted opposition from both local and national groups.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.norwichn25.org/ |title=home |publisher=Norwich No N25 Campaign |accessdate=2008-11-09}}</ref>
===Priory Park, Southend=== {{main|Camp Bling}} Southend Borough Council wishes to build road to upgrade [[A1159 road|A1159]]/Priory Crescent in Southend in a dual carriageway.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thesietch.org/mysietch/parklife/campaign-background/|title=campaign background|accessdate=2008-11-09}}</ref>
The [[Camp Bling]] protest camp was established in 2005<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/essex/4672900.st |title=The battle for the 'King of Bling' |work=BBC News |date=2008-02-06 |accessdate=2008-11-09 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> and was still active in October 2008 and intending to stay in place until the road is scrapped.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.freewebs.com/campbling/aboutthecamp.htm |title = About the camp |publisher = Camp Bling |accessdate = 2008-11-09 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081026005214/http://www.freewebs.com/campbling/aboutthecamp.htm |archivedate = 26 October 2008 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> At a meeting with the council in April 2009 the authority told the protesters that the road widening scheme had been abandoned<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.southend.gov.uk/news/default.asp?id=2835 |title=Priory Crescent update |date=2009-04-16 |accessdate=2010-02-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090428090030/http://www.southend.gov.uk/news/default.asp?id=2835 |archivedate=28 April 2009 }}</ref> and the protesters agreed to leave.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.echo-news.co.uk/news/4310893.Protesters_poised_to_leave_Camp_Bling/|title=Protesters poised to leave Camp Bling|work=Echo news|date=2009-04-23|accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref>
===Whaplode and Moulton bypass=== In May 2007, the Spalding Guardian reported again that campaigners were calling for a bypass around the Lincolnshire villages of [[Whaplode]] and [[Moulton, Lincolnshire|Moulton]] to be made a top priority. This call followed another fatal collision on the [[A151 road]] in Moulton. Measures which have already been taken on the road, including lower [[speed limit]]s and [[speed camera]]s, haven't stopped the increasing death toll.<ref>{{cite news |title=Just how many more must die? |date=2007-05-31 |publisher=Spalding Guardian |url=http://www.spaldingtoday.co.uk/news/Just-how-many-more-must.2916973.jp |accessdate=2008-01-21 }}</ref> The current campaign to have a bypass built started in 2002. In June 2004 the campaign group ''WRATH''' (Whaplode Residents Against Traffic Horror) was launched to lobby for the bypass. In January 2005 ''WRATH'' submitted a proposed route for the bypass to Lincolnshire County Council.<ref>{{cite news |title=Call for bypass: the story so far |date=2007-05-31 |publisher=Spalding Guardian |url=http://www.spaldingtoday.co.uk/bypass/Call-for-bypass-the-story.2916675.jp |accessdate=2008-01-21 }}</ref> In July 2007, ''WRATH'' organised a three-mile (5 km) protest march through the villages to publicise their campaign. A Lincolnshire county councillor was reported to have said that there were twenty one other villages in Lincolnshire saying they had a need for a bypass.<ref>{{cite news |title=We want a bypass |date=2007-07-17 |publisher=Spalding Guardian |url=http://www.spaldingtoday.co.uk/bypass/We-want-a-bypass-.3033899.jp |accessdate=2008-01-21 }}</ref>
===Others=== [[File:Road protest, Bilston Glen - geograph.org.uk - 32387.jpg|thumb|Road protest, Bilston Glen, Scotland]] Other active protests include the ones against the following schemes: The South Bristol Link Road, Weymouth Relief Road, Bilston Glen,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bilstonglen-abs.org.uk|title=bilstonglen-abs.org.uk - The alternative lifestyle bilstonglen-abs.org.uk|publisher=}}</ref> M6 widening, Bexhill to Hastings Link Road, Heysham to M6 Link, Kingskerswell Bypass, M1 Widening, Aberdeen Bypass, and the Westbury Bypass. In Ireland there is a protest opposed to bypassing the town of Slane with a new [[N2 road (Ireland)|N2 dual carriageway]] which will pass a few kilometres from the [[Newgrange]] ancient monument.
==Past protests==
===1950–1979=== {{see also|Road protest in the United Kingdom#1950-1979|Roads in the United Kingdom#1950-1979}}
===1979–1997=== {{see also|Road protest in the United Kingdom#1979-1997|Roads in the United Kingdom#1979-1997}}
===1997–the present day=== {{see also|Road protest in the United Kingdom#1997-the present day|Roads in the United Kingdom#1997-the present day}}
====A66 Temple Sowerby bypass==== The bypass around [[Temple Sowerby]] opened October 2007. The bypass aims to reduce traffic in the village by 95%.<ref>{{cite web |title=Temple Sowerby motorists get £36.6 million bypass |publisher=Ordnance Survey |date=2007-10-20 |url=http://leisure.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/leisure/tscontent/editorial/motoring/2007/pennineroad.html |accessdate=2008-01-21 }}</ref> Locals had been calling for a bypass since the 1960s. In 1974 the government announced plans to build one, but these were abandoned in 1983. This was followed by years of increasingly vocal protests.<ref>{{cite web |title=TEMPLE SOWERBY BYPASS TWISTS ANDTURNS OF A LONG-RUNNING CAMPAIGN |publisher=Cumberland and Westmorland Herald |date=2007-10-19 |url=http://www.cwherald.com/archive/archive/temple-sowerby-bypass--twists-andturns-of-a-long%11running-campaign-20071019298637.htm |accessdate=2008-01-21 }}</ref>
====M74 Extension==== {{see also|M74 motorway}}
[[Transport Scotland]] planned for some time to extend the [[A74(M) and M74 motorways|M74]] by five miles to link it to the [[M8 motorway (Scotland)|M8]].<ref>{{cite web |title=M74 Completion |url=http://www.transportscotland.gov.uk/headlineprojectpage.aspx?pageID=311 |publisher=Transport Scotland}}</ref> The M74 Extension, also known as 'M74 Completion' and 'M74 Northern Extension', extended the M74 northwards by {{convert|5|mi|km}} through the south-eastern suburbs of [[Dalmarnock]], [[Polmadie]], [[Rutherglen, Glasgow|Rutherglen]], [[Govanhill]] and the [[Gorbals]] to meet the M8 near the [[Kingston Bridge, Glasgow|Kingston Bridge]] in Glasgow on an elevated embankment. The Scottish Executive reported that the scheme will lead to a wealthier and fairer, healthier, safer and stronger, and greener future.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transportscotland.gov.uk/headlineprojectpage.aspx?pageID=707|title=M74 - Benefits|publisher=Transport Scotland|accessdate=2008-01-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214143209/http://www.transportscotland.gov.uk/headlineprojectpage.aspx?pageID=707|archivedate=14 December 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, JAM74, a coalition of community, environmental and sustainable transport groups, believed the scheme will be detrimental.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jam74.org/?page_id=22|title=Resources|publisher=Jam74|accessdate=2008-01-20}}</ref>
In May 2003, the Green and Socialist MSPs joined local campaigners to stop the project.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/3018157.stm|title=Parties unite to fight M74 plans|date=2003-05-11|work=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=2008-01-21}}</ref> A [[public inquiry]] for the scheme ran from December 2003 until March 2004 and the report, not published until March 2005<ref>{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4156/is_20050327/ai_n13482480 |title=M74 verdict: not the end of the road |work=Sunday Herald |date=2005-03-27 |author=Rob Edwards |accessdate=2008-08-20 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> recommended against the building of the road, saying that it would "be very likely to have very serious undesirable results".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/library5/transport/m74r-00.asp/|title=REPORT OF PUBLIC LOCAL INQUIRY INTO OBJECTIONS|publisher=The Scottish Government|date=2005-03-24|accessdate=2008-01-21}}</ref> The transport secretary at the time, [[Nicol Stephen]], simultaneously announced that insufficient weight had been given to the economic benefits that the scheme would bring and that they would proceed with the scheme.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2005/03/24181414|title=M74 link gets go ahead|publisher=Scottish Government|date=2005-03-24|accessdate=2008-01-21}}</ref> [[Friends of the Earth Scotland]] said that it was "probably the worst environmental decision ever taken by the Scottish Executive" and that they would challenge the decision in court<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/4379553.stm|title=Legal threat after M74 decision|work=[[BBC News]]|date=2005-03-24|accessdate=2008-01-20}}</ref> but then withdrew it in June 2006 on legal advice.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/glasgow_and_west/5125214.stm|title=Motorway court action abandoned|work=[[BBC News]]|date=2006-06-28|accessdate=2008-01-20}}</ref> In September 2004, the EU ruled that land on which the road was to be built should be classified as hazardous due to [[Shawfield#Toxic legacy|chromium dumps]] buried underground.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/3666448.stm|title=Euro ruling doubt over M74 plans|work=[[BBC News]]|date=2004-09-17|accessdate=2008-01-21}}</ref>
Construction work started in 2008, and the road opened on 28 June 2011. The extension involved the demolition of the [[Rosebery Park]] football ground.

{{Refimprove|date=April 2007}} [[Image:ISO 7010 E007.svg|thumb|ISO standardized [[pictogram]] for a [[fire safety]] assembly point]] [[File:Airport Oslo Gardermoen - Meeting point.jpg|240px|right|thumb|A signed meeting point at the airport Oslo Gardermoen]] A '''meeting point''', '''meeting place''', or '''assembly point''' is a geographically defined place where people meet. Such a meeting point is often a [[landmark]] which has become popular and is a convenient place for both [[tourist]]s and [[citizen]]s to meet. Examples of meeting points include public areas and facilities such as squares, statues, parks, amusement parks, railway stations, airports, etc. or officially designated and signed points in such public facilities. There is often a public sign designating an official meeting point in public facilities (see illustrations).
Especially when called an ''assembly point'', a meeting point is a designated (safe) place where people can gather or must report to during an [[emergency]] or a fire drill etc.<ref>[http://www.oxfordshire.gov.uk/cms/content/fire-drill-routine-schools]</ref>
In [[sociology]], a meeting point is a place where a group of people meet on a regular basis, for example a group of regulars or people with a special interest or background. These meeting points are in designated private rooms, in a part of a park, or in a [[café]]. Sites like [http://meetways.com/ meetways.com] can help people find a meeting point between two addresses.
==Examples of well-known meeting points==
===Australia=== * [[Brisbane]] - [[Hungry Jack's]] on [[Queen Street Mall]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://city-news.whereilive.com.au/news/story/hungry-jacks-a-hub/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110115173351/http://city-news.whereilive.com.au/news/story/hungry-jacks-a-hub/ |archivedate=2011-01-15 |df= }}</ref> * [[Melbourne]] - "Under the Clocks" at [[Flinders Street Station]]<ref>http://www.tripadvisor.com.au/ShowUserReviews-g255100-d526963-r15626238-Flinders_Street_Station-Melbourne_Victoria.html</ref> * [[Adelaide]] - "Malls Balls" at [[Rundle Mall]]<ref>http://www.scenicadelaide.com/2008/08/30/the-rundle-mall-balls-meeting-place-for-young-and-old/</ref> * [[Sydney]] - "Town Hall Steps" at [[Sydney Town Hall]] <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/sydneytownhall/hiring-town-hall-surrounds.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121204185936/http://www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/sydneytownhall/hiring-town-hall-surrounds.asp |archivedate=2012-12-04 |df= }}</ref>
===Denmark=== * [[Copenhagen]] - "Under uret" - ''Under the clock'' - at [[Københavns Hovedbanegård]].<ref>http://www.hovedbanen.dk/</ref>
===Nicaragua=== * [[El Ostional]] - "Centro Ole" - ''Ole Center'' - at [[O Parks, WildLife, and Recreation]].<ref>http://www.opwr.org/</ref>
===[[Sweden]]===
* [[:sv:Svampen, Stockholm|Svampen]], "the mushroom", a mushroom shaped structure on [[Stureplan]], [[Stockholm]]. * [[:sv:Ringen på Stockholms centralstation|Ringen på centralen]], "the ring at the central station", a fenced, circle-shaped opening between two levels at the [[Stockholm Central Station|Central Station]], [[Stockholm]].
===[[Poland]]===
* [[Wrocław]], there are two popular meeting spots on Wrocław's [[Market Square, Wrocław|Market Square]] - "the pillory" and statue of [[Aleksander Fredro]].

Winner's result at [[Eurovision Song Contest|Eurovision]]: | 19th |} '''[[Melodifestivalen]] 2005''' was the selection for the 45th song to represent Sweden at the [[Eurovision Song Contest]]. It was the 44th time that this system of picking a song had been used. Five semifinals had taken place to select the ten songs for the final, in [[Gothenburg]], [[Linköping]], [[Skellefteå]], [[Växjö]] and a Second Chance round in [[Stockholm]]. The final was broadcast on [[SVT1]] and [[Sveriges Radio]]'s P4 network. [[Nanne Grönvall]]'s defeat was met with consternation by many people, who felt that a gap of over 150,000 votes should be enough for victory. There were even calls for SVT to scrap the jury system altogether and simply let the televotes decide the winner. For a comparison, it was noted that Grönvall had received more votes than Lena Philipsson, the popular 2004 winner. However, SVT said that there was nothing they could do about the result. Four finalists topped the Swedish charts. [[Alcazar (group)|Alcazar]] and ''Alcastar'' got to number one the week before the final, [[Jimmy Jansson]] got to the number one some weeks after that with ''Vi kan gunga'', [[Martin Stenmarck]]'s winner ''Las Vegas'' hit the top spot the week after that, while Nanne Grönvall and ''Håll om mig'' topped the charts the week after that. ==Semifinals== The '''semifinals for Melodifestivalen 2005''' began on 12 February 2005. Ten songs from these semifinals qualified for the final on March 12, 2005. {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Use Indian English|date=February 2016}} {{Jainism}} '''Panch Kalyanaka''' ({{lang-sa|pan̄ca kalyāṇaka}}, "Five Auspicious Events") are the five chief auspicious events that are believed to occur in the life of [[tirthankara]] in [[Jainism]].<ref name=kt>{{Cite book|last=Titze|first=Kurt|title=Jainism: A Pictorial Guide to the Religion of Non-Violence|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass Publ.|isbn=9788120815346|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=loQkEIf8z5wC&pg=PA262&dq=kalyanaka+bhumi#v=onepage&q=kalyanaka%20bhumi&f=false|accessdate=10 December 2012|page=262|year=1998}}</ref><ref name=psj>{{Cite book|last=Jaini|first=Padmanabh S.|title=The Jaina Path Of Purification|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass Publ.|isbn=9788120815780|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wE6v6ahxHi8C&pg=PA343&dq=kalyanaka+bhumi#v=onepage&q=kalyanaka%20bhumi&f=false|accessdate=10 December 2012|pages=196, 343, 347|year=1998}}</ref><ref name=jsm>{{Cite book|last=Mehta|first=Jodh Sinha|title=Abu to Udaipur: (Celestial Simla to City of Sunrise)|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass Publisher|isbn=9788185066172|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q6FpVLjVzU8C&pg=PA20&dq=jain+kalyanak#v=onepage&q=jain%20kalyanak&f=false|accessdate=10 December 2012|page=20|year=1970}}</ref> They are commemorated as part of many [[Jain rituals]] and festivals.<ref name=jc>{{Cite book|last=Cort|first=John E.|title=Jains in the World: Religious Values and Ideology in India|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195132342|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PZk-4HOMzsoC&pg=PA110&dq=jain+kalyanak#v=snippet&q=kalyanak&f=false|accessdate=10 December 2012|page=110|year=2001}}</ref>
==Kalyanaka==
These auspicious life events are as below:<ref name=jsm/><ref name=jc/><ref name=kl>{{Cite book|last=Lal|first=Kanwar|title=Holy cities of India|publisher=Asia Press|isbn=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IWdDAAAAYAAJ&q=jain+kalyanak+bhumi&dq=jain+kalyanak+bhumi|accessdate=10 December 2012|pages=59|year=1961}}</ref><ref name=jiv>{{Cite book|last=Eberhard Fischer|first=Jyotindra Jain|title=Jaina Iconography, Volume 1|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789004052598|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gFZ7vQ2jwlEC&pg=PA15&dq=jain+tirthankara#v=onepage&q=jain%20tirthankara&f=false|accessdate=11 December 2012|pages=4–13|year=1978}}</ref> # Cyavana kalyāṇaka: When the [[ātman (Jainism)|ātman]] (soul) of a tirthankara enter's their mother's womb.<ref name=hck>{{cite web|title=Chyavana Kalyanak|url=http://www.herenow4u.net/index.php?id=74859|work=|publisher=www.herenow4u.net|accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> # Janma kalyāṇaka: Birth of the tirthankara.<ref name=psj/><ref name=hck/> [[Jain rituals and festivals#Worship of Jain idols|Snatra Puja]] is a ritual celebrating this event in which [[Indra#In Buddhism, Jainism, Taoism and Bali|Indra]] does [[abhisheka]] on the tirthankara on [[Mount Meru]].<ref name=kw>{{Cite book|last=Wiley|first=Kristi L.|title=The A to Z of Jainism|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810868212|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kUz9o-EKTpwC&pg=PA22&dq=snatra+puja#v=onepage&q=snatra%20puja&f=false|accessdate=10 December 2012|pages=200, 246|year=2009}}</ref> # Dīkṣā kalyāṇaka: When a tirthankara renounce all worldly possessions and becomes an ascetic.<ref name=hdk>{{cite web|title=Diksha Kalyanak|url=http://www.herenow4u.net/index.php?id=74861|work=|publisher=www.herenow4u.net|accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> # Kēvalajñāna kalyāṇaka: The event when a tirthankara attains [[Kevala Jnana|kēvalajñāna]] (absolute knowledge). A divine [[samavasarana]] (preaching hall) appears, from where the tirthankara delivers sermons and restores the [[Jain community]] and teachings.<ref name=hkk>{{cite web|title=Kevaljnana Kalyanak|url=http://www.herenow4u.net/index.php?id=74862|work=|publisher=www.herenow4u.net|accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> # Nirvāṇa kalyāṇaka: When a tirthankara leaves their mortal body, it is known as [[nirvana]]. It is followed by final liberation, [[Moksha (Jainism)|moksha]]. A tirthankara is considered a [[Siddha#Siddha in Jainism|Siddha]] after that.<ref name=hnk>{{cite web|title=Nirvana Kalyanak|url=http://www.herenow4u.net/index.php?id=74863|work=|publisher=www.herenow4u.net|accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref><ref name=rd>{{Cite book|last=Dalal|first=Roshen|title=The Religions of India: A Concise Guide to Nine Major Faiths|publisher=Penguin Books India|isbn=9780143415176|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pNmfdAKFpkQC&pg=PA368&dq=tirthankara+place+of+birth#v=onepage&q=tirthankara%20place%20of%20birth&f=false|accessdate=11 December 2012|page=369|year=2010}}</ref>
{{Gallery |title=Pancha Kalyanaka of Mahavira, folios from ''[[Kalpasutra (Jain)|Kalpasutra]]'', loose leaf manuscript, [[Patan, Gujarat]]. c. 1472 (now in Brooklyn Museum) |File:Kalpasutra Queen Trishalas dream.jpg|Cyavana kalyāṇaka |File:Brooklyn Museum - Page 40 from a manuscript of the Kalpasutra recto image of Jamnabhisheka verso text.jpg|Janma kalyāṇaka |File:Kalpasutra Mahavira Varsidaan.jpg|Dīkṣā kalyāṇaka |File:Samosarana Mahaviras enlightenment.jpg|Kēvalajñāna kalyāṇaka |File:Kalpasutra Mahavira Nirvana.jpg|Nirvāṇa kalyāṇaka }}
==Kalyanaka Dates of 24 Tirthankara==
These dates are called ''Kalyanaka Tithi''. All dates are considered according to Jain calendar known as ''Jain Panchang'' based on the [[Vira Nirvana Samvat]], but they differ according to different sects of Jain tradition and sometimes different within the same tradition also.<ref name=jup>{{cite web|title=PANCH KALYANAK of 24 TIRTHANKAR|url=http://www.jainuniversity.org/Panch_Kalyank_of_24_Tirthankar.aspx|work=|publisher=jainuniversity.org|accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref><ref name=jtf>{{cite web|title=Kalyanak Year 2012-13|url=http://www.jain24.org/index.php/panchang/25-tirthankaras|work=|publisher=www.jain24.org|accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref><ref name=jpj>{{cite web|title=Jain Panchang 2010-Page 2|url=http://www.jaindial.com/PDF/Jain_Panchang/Gujarati_Jain_Panchang.pdf|work=jaindial.com/Jain_Panchang.asp|publisher=www.jaindial.com|accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref><ref name=mjs>{{cite web|title=Activity / Tithi Calendar showing Feb-2011/Posh-Maha month Kalyanaka|url=http://www.melbournejainsangh.org/index.php?mact=Calendar,m6,default,1&m6year=2011&m6month=2&m6returnid=86&page=86|work=www.melbournejainsangh.org|publisher=Melbourne Jain Sangh|accessdate=11 December 2012}}</ref>

==Kalyanaka Places of 24 Tirthankara== '''Kalyanaka Bhumi''' are places where any of these Kalyanaka took place in relation to 24 [[Tirthankara]]. They are considered places of pilgrimage by Jains.<ref name=kl/> 20 out of 24 [[Tirthankara]]s' Nirvana kalyanaka took place at [[Shikharji]].<ref name=rd/>

==Rituals== {{Main article|Jain rituals}} Some rituals have close relationshhip with these five Kalyanakas.
===Jain temple erection=== {{Main article|Panch-kalyanak Pratishtha}} When a new [[Jain Temple]] is erected, these Five Auspicious Life Events are celebrated known as ''Panch Kalyanak Pratishtha Mahotsava''. It is followed by ''Anjana Shalaka'', a ceremony to install new [[Tirthankara]] icon. An [[Acharya#In Jainism|Acharya]] recite ''mantra''s related to Panch Kalyanaka followed by applying special paste to eyes of [[Tirthankara]] image. After these an icons of [[Tirthankara]] gets a status of real [[Tirthankara]] which can be worshipped by Jains. [[Acharya#In Jainism|Acharya]] have to fast for three days before that.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Jaini|first=Padmanabh S.|title=The Jaina Path Of Purification|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass Publ.|isbn=9788120815780|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wE6v6ahxHi8C&pg=PA343&dq=kalyanaka+bhumi#v=onepage&q=kalyanaka%20bhumi&f=false|accessdate=10 December 2012|pages=196–199|year=1998}}</ref>
===Worship rituals=== ''Panch Kalyanaka Puja'' is a ritual solemnizes all five Kalyanaka. It was narrated by Pandit Virvijay.
''Snatra Puja'' is a ritual related to Janma Kalyanaka in which icons of [[Tirthankara]] are bathed symbolising [[Indra#In Buddhism, Jainism, Taoism and Bali|Indra]] doing [[Abhisheka]] on [[Tirthankara]] on [[Mount Meru]] after birth of [[Tirthankara]]. It performed before many other rituals and before starting of new enterprises, birthdays.<ref name=kw/>
==Festivals== {{Main article|Jain festivals}} Many religious festivals mark Kalyanaka of [[Tirthankara]] especially Janma and Nirvana Kalyanaka.
===Mahavir Jayanti=== {{Main article|Mahavir Jayanti}} It marks Janma Kalyanak (birth) of 24th Tirthankara, [[Mahavira]]. [[Abhisheka]] of icons are done on this day and procession celebrating this event takes place in the cities. It is on 13th day of bright half of Chaitra month of [[Jain calendar]] (March/April).<ref name=kw/>
===Diwali=== {{Main article|Diwali#Jainism}} [[Diwali]] is a day of Nirvana Kalyanaka of 24th Tirthankara, [[Mahavira]]. He attained [[Moksha (Jainism)|Moksha]] on this day in 527 BCE. It falls on fifteenth day of dark half of Ashwin (Aaso) month (September/October) which is also a last day of a year.<ref name=kw/>
===Pausha Dashmi=== It is celebrated on 10th day of dark half of Pausha (Pushya) month of [[Hindu calendar]](December/January). It marks Janma kalyanaka (birth) of 23rd Tirthankara, [[Parshvanath]]. Three days fast is observed by many Jains.
===Maun Agiyaras=== Maun Agiyaras or Ekadashi marks Kalyanaka of many Tirthankaras. It is celebrated on 11th day of Magshar month of [[Jain calendar]] (October/November). On this day, complete silence is observed and fasting is kept. Meditation is also performed.<ref name=kw/>

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Parachute Music Festival | image = Parachute-Mainstage-Late-Afternoon.JPG | caption = Parachute 2010 Mainstage in the late afternoon before headliners at night | landscape = yes | origin = El Rancho Christian Camp, Waikanae, New Zealand | other_former_locations = Totara Springs, Matamata, New Zealand | current_location = Mystery Creek Events Centre, Hamilton, New Zealand | years_active = 1991-2014 | label = [[Parachute Music]] Ltd. | background = group_or_band }}
The '''Parachute Music Festival''' was a [[Christian music festival]] held annually in various venues in New Zealand between 1992 - 2014 with the event being held at [[Mystery Creek Events Centre]], [[Hamilton, New Zealand]] from 2004. It was previously held at [[Totara Springs]] in [[Matamata]] and [[El Rancho, Waikanae|El Rancho]], [[Waikanae]] The festival was run by [[Parachute Music]] and usually lasted for three nights and four days. It was held the weekend before [[Auckland Anniversary Day]],<ref>[http://ripitup.co.nz/topic/parachute-music-festival/684] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308114204/http://ripitup.co.nz/topic/parachute-music-festival/684 |date=March 8, 2012 }}</ref> in late January. 'Parachute' was one of the largest Christian music festivals outside of the United States and it was one of the largest multi-day festivals in the Southern Hemisphere.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.infonews.co.nz/news.cfm?id=31333 |title=Parachute lends a hand to NZ Women's Refuge|publisher=Infonews.co.nz|date= |accessdate=2015-07-05}}</ref><ref>[https://archive.is/20130223023401/http://www.stuff.co.nz/nelson-mail/entertainment/2830835/Inspirational-rock-spirit]</ref> Primarily featuring musicians and guest speakers, the festival was also the longest running festival of any kind in New Zealand.<ref name="stuff.co.nz">{{cite web|author=Siena Yates|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/waikato-times/news/8161711/Christian-festival-hits-helpful-note |title=Christian festival hits helpful note|publisher=Stuff.co.nz|date=2013-01-10|accessdate=2015-07-05}}</ref>
==About== [[File:LunchVillagecrowd.JPG|thumb|The Lunch crowd in the Village food stall area.]]
The Parachute Music Festival attracted around 25,000 people each year. The largest crowd came in 2007, with 27,813 attendees. Most people who attend stay on-site in tents and caravans, and a large village area supplies food, amenities and band merchandise.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/parachute-music-festival/news/headlines.cfm?c_id=1500869 |title=Parachute Music Festival |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref>
Each year artists apply to play at Parachute which gives an opportunity for musicians to have their music heard by a large audience at a popular event. Bands applying must have a pastoral reference, that is a reference from a church leader, to ensure that the core members of any act are committed Christians. In some cases individual members of a band will not be Christian but Parachute see this as a good way to involve people in the festival community.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parachutefestival.com/info/faqs|title=FAQ’s | Parachute Music Festival 2014|publisher=Parachutefestival.com|date=|accessdate=2015-07-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706160638/http://www.parachutefestival.com/info/faqs/|archive-date=2015-07-06|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> While many local bands from New Zealand apply, Parachute receive applications from all over the world. Parachute Music also invite a number of headline artists each year to perform at the festival. Around 100 bands from many different genres play at Parachute each year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amplifier.co.nz/news/75264/parachute-festival-applications-open.html|title=Parachute Festival Applications Open|publisher=Amplifier.co.nz|date=|accessdate=2015-07-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110190927/http://www.amplifier.co.nz/news/75264/parachute-festival-applications-open.html|archive-date=2016-01-10|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
The festival is aimed at a wide demographic ranging from families to teenagers. It is classified as a non-denominational Christian event, with enforced bans on drugs or alcohol and unmarried couples being discouraged from tenting together. However, a large percentage of non-Christian people do attend. Because Parachute is a [[non-denominational]] Christian festival, events such as Catholic Mass and Anglican Eucharist take place over the weekend.
The Festival is covered by most New Zealand media and is a well known event of the New Zealand summer. It has also been supported by and has been in partnerships with a number of businesses and organisations - Some examples are [[Coca-Cola]], [[Sanitarium Health Food Company|Sanitarium]], [[V (drink)|V]], [[Pepsi]], [[Vodafone New Zealand|Vodafone]] and The [[NZ Police]].
Parachute is often in partnerships with charities<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.challengeweekly.co.nz/national/1998-justice-at-p12-parachute-festival-2012.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130209160317/http://challengeweekly.co.nz/national/1998-justice-at-p12-parachute-festival-2012.html |archivedate=2013-02-09 |df= }}</ref> such as, [[World Vision]]. Parachute Music have been working with World Vision since 2006 to sponsor a village in Rwanda called Tubehoneza. Over the last six festivals, festival-goers have donated $303,000 to the area. This money has been used to build five water tanks, three classrooms, a maternity unit and a health centre for Tubehoneza. Also through the festival 1,900 children have been sponsored.<ref>[http://festival.parachutemusic.com/causes/world-vision] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111023131052/http://festival.parachutemusic.com/causes/world-vision |date=October 23, 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.parachutefestival.com/causes/tubehoneza] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208124545/http://www.parachutefestival.com/causes/tubehoneza |date=February 8, 2013 }}</ref>
==History== In 1992, the first 'Parachute Music Festival' was staged at El Rancho Christian Holiday Camp, [[Waikanae]]. In 1995, the festival moved north to a larger venue at Totara Springs Christian Centre, [[Matamata]]. The most recent move was in 2004 to the [[Mystery Creek Events Centre]], just outside [[Hamilton, New Zealand|Hamilton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parachutemusic.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=12&Itemid=76|title=Parachute Music|date=|accessdate=2015-07-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120218194128/http://www.parachutemusic.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=12&Itemid=76|archivedate=2012-02-18|df=}}</ref> The festival has remained at Mystery Creek and in 2008, Parachute Music signed a contract with Mystery Creek Events Centre that kept the festival at the venue for five more years.<ref>{{cite web|authors=Louise Risk & Maryanne Twentyman|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/waikato-times/entertainment/6286569/Music-festival-competition-fierce |title=Music festival competition fierce|publisher=Stuff.co.nz|date= |accessdate=2015-07-05}}</ref> At the end of 2012, Parachute Music renewed this contract with Mystery Creek ensuring that Parachute would again take place at the events centre for the next five years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mysterycreek.co.nz/five-year-contract-signed-parachute-music-festival/ |title=Parachute Music Festival organisers sign a five-year contract with Mystery Creek Events Centre |publisher=Mysterycreek.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2015-07-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706134537/http://www.mysterycreek.co.nz/five-year-contract-signed-parachute-music-festival/ |archivedate=2015-07-06 |df= }}</ref>
In 2010, Parachute Festival celebrated its 20th birthday with a large party at Mainstage and a fireworks display.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boomboom.co.nz/ParachuteMusicCaseStudy/tabid/33086/Default.aspx |title=Parachute Music 20th Birthday Fireworks |publisher=Boomboom.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2015-07-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113063046/http://boomboom.co.nz/ParachuteMusicCaseStudy/tabid/33086/Default.aspx |archivedate=2015-01-13 |df= }}</ref>
Parachute saw that families were unable to attend the festival due to a tough financial climate and introduced the 'Pay What You Can Afford' initiative for the 2012 festival where punters were able to pay for a family pass and choose from a price as low as $1.<ref>[http://ripitup.co.nz/contentitem/news-parachute-festival-offers-pay-what-you-can-afford-family-passes/2959] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120921142954/http://ripitup.co.nz/contentitem/news-parachute-festival-offers-pay-what-you-can-afford-family-passes/2959 |date=September 21, 2012 }}</ref> A similar programme under the same name was introduced for the 2013 festival where people were able to donate money to a 'Pay What You Can Afford' account and for every $200 raised, a family were able to attend the festival for free.<ref name="stuff.co.nz"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://fundraise.givealittle.co.nz/?p=1246 |title=Givealittle - Home |publisher=Fundraise.givealittle.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2015-07-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140720193909/http://fundraise.givealittle.co.nz/?p=1246 |archivedate=2014-07-20 |df= }}</ref>
Mystery Creek Events Centre began a long-term major redevelopment in 2012, so limited gate access and venue space is available for the festival. For the first time in the festival's history, ticket numbers were capped off at 17,500 weekend passes and 1,500 day passes. After launching a festival app for Android and Apple devices in 2012,<ref>[http://www.lifefm.co.nz/index.php/music-news/item/197-parachute-2012-app] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208035403/http://www.lifefm.co.nz/index.php/music-news/item/197-parachute-2012-app |date=February 8, 2013 }}</ref> Parachute Festival will also launch technology where one can buy items at festival by scanning a festival wristband instead of paying with cash or cards in 2013.<ref>[http://www.parachutemusic.com/events/parachute-2013] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718192535/http://www.parachutemusic.com/events/parachute-2013 |date=July 18, 2012 }}</ref>
In 2013, Parachute also restructured the festival to run as a 'three-day' event, rather than a four-day event which it has done in the past. This means that nothing will be programmed after midnight on Sunday but festival-goers will still be able to leave at their leisure on Monday.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nzmusic.org.nz/news/artist/parachute-festival-2013-important-announcements/ |title=Parachute Festival 2013 Important Announcements|publisher=Nzmusic.org.nz|date=2012-07-17|accessdate=2015-07-05}}</ref> Also in 2013, Parachute became New Zealand's longest running festival, having been running its festival annually for 23 years.<ref name="stuff.co.nz"/>
On March 27, 2014 Parachute Music released a statement on its Facebook and its website announcing that Parachute Music Festival would no longer be running.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parachutefestival.com/ |title=Parachute Music Festival 2014|publisher=Parachutefestival.com|date= |accessdate=2015-07-05}}</ref> The closing set at the final Parachute was performed by local metalcore/hardcore band East of Eden.
In 2015 the multi-day [[Festival One]] will replace Parachute Festival in Mystery Creek, (and the single-day [[Cloud Festival]] in [[Auckland]]). These events feature many of the same artists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lifefm.co.nz/music/item/382-festival-one-2015 |title=Festival One 2015 Announced|publisher=Lifefm.co.nz|date= |accessdate=2015-07-05}}</ref>

Popular local bands have played Parachute as 'local Headliners.' In past festivals the line up has included the likes of [[Mumsdollar]], [[Steriogram]], [[The Lads]], [[Brooke Fraser]], [[juliagrace]], [[Kingston (band)|Kingston]], [[Ruby Frost]], [[Late 80's Mercedes]], The Glory Sea, and many others. Often Australian bands are put on the 'local Headliner' list.
In mid-2012, Parachute Music ran a competition to find a local band that would open the 2013 festival. A judging panel chose five bands that had entered and the decision was left to be made by public vote. The winner of this competition was hardcore band Saving Grace, from [[Gisborne, New Zealand|Gisborne]]. Saving Grace will be the first to play on Parachute's Mainstage for the 23rd festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parachutemusic.com/news/local-news/1071-the-opener |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120907060004/http://www.parachutemusic.com/news/local-news/1071-the-opener |dead-url=yes |archive-date=7 September 2012 |title=Parachute Music |work=parachutemusic.com |accessdate=5 July 2015 }}</ref>
Representing dance and electronic music over the years have been DJs and MCs including [[Andy Hunter (DJ)|Andy Hunter]], Tim Richards, Andy Pulzar, Dr Siminz, Paul Spain/MC Preacher Boy and DJ U-gene. In 2013 Parachute introduced the 'Rewired Dance Parties' to the Palladium stage. These dance parties include DJ sets from festival headliners.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parachutefestival.com/programme/fun-stuff|title=Fun Stuff|work=parachutefestival.com|accessdate=5 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706141416/http://www.parachutefestival.com/programme/fun-stuff/|archive-date=2015-07-06|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
=== Cancellations === * [[Hawk Nelson]] were scheduled to play in 2007 and 2008 but double bookings prevented them from making it. * [[Flyleaf (band)|Flyleaf]] were scheduled to play in 2011 but due to a band member's pregnancy, they had to pull out of the festival. [[Elemeno P]] replaced Flyleaf which caused some controversy over Elemeno P not being 'Christian' enough.<ref name="TVNZ_4007983">{{cite news |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/entertainment-news/elemeno-p-not-christian-enough-parachute-4007983 |title=Elemeno P not Christian enough for Parachute? |date=26 January 2011 |work=[[One News (New Zealand)|One News]] |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref>

media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7n3qvCnflGM |title=PARACHUTE '08 PROMO VIDEO|date=5 December 2007|work=YouTube|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref> * 2009: Brian Houston, [[Tim Costello]], Chris web|url=http://www.muzic.net.nz/gig-guide/news/2072/last-chance-for-parachute-2011-earlybird-tickets-.html |title=Last chance for Parachute 2011 Earlybird tickets|work=muzic.net.nz|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Parachute-2011-Music-mayhem-head-to-Hamilton/tabid/418/articleID/195782/Default.aspx |title=Parachute 2011 Music mayhem head to Hamilton|work=3news.co.nz|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref> * 2012: [[Darlene Zschech]], Tim Costello<ref>{{cite web|url=http://parachute.vps1.netpotential.co.nz/lineup/speakers |title=Parachute 2012 - Speakers |work=netpotential.co.nz |accessdate=5 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110190926/http://parachute.vps1.netpotential.co.nz/lineup/speakers |archivedate=10 Young|Paul Young]]<ref>[http://www.parachutefestival.com/lineup/speakers] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208124050/http://www.parachutefestival.com/lineup/speakers |date=February 8, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parachutefestival.com/programme/festival|title=Festival Programme|work=parachutefestival.com|accessdate=5 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208124203/http://www.parachutefestival.com/programme/festival|archive-date=2013-02-08|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> * 2014: [[Erwin McManus]], [[Brian Sumner]], [[Invisible Children, Inc.|Ben Keesey]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parachutefestival.com/line-up/|title=Line Up - Parachute Music Festival 2014|work=parachutefestival.com|accessdate=5 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924064011/http://www.parachutefestival.com/line-up/|archive-date=2015-09-24|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==Other attractions== Events and attractions that usually take place at Parachute: *[[Amusement rides]], inflatables and carnival games *[[Water slide]] *[[Paintball]] * Kids programme *[[Skatepark]] *Market shopping at 'The Village' *Punters vs. international artist competitions - there have been Cook offs, volleyball, cricket and more. *Parachute's Got Talent competition *Themed parties, each year the theme may change. For example, - An 80s party, barn dance, [[silent disco]], roller disco *Noise, a collection of seminars/workshops from international and local artists on music and performance, with some seminars and workshops focusing more on the technical (production) side of performances *Movie screenings and film festivals
==Stages== Each stage at Parachute Festival is designed to have a different feel and environment, and sometimes the stages are set for certain genres of music. Stages for 2014 are:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parachutefestival.com/programme/|title=Programme|work=parachutefestival.com|accessdate=5 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705202014/http://www.parachutefestival.com/programme/|archive-date=2015-07-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> * Mainstage * Palladium * Deluxe * Massive * White Elephant
===Other venues=== * The Seminar Space - Holds seminars and speaker segments. It is also the venue which holds events such as Catholic mass. * Noise Venue - This venue hosts Parachute Music's Noise programme which is aimed at developing Christian artists. * Village Stage - The Village stage is an acoustic stage in the heart of the main Parachute shopping and food area.
===Former stages=== [[File:ParachuteMainstage.jpg|thumb|Parachute Festival's Mainstage in 2007]]
Parachute Festival's mainstage is often given a new look and in 2009, Parachute Music used a completely new mainstage for the festival. The mainstage used from 2009-2011 was New Zealand's largest concert stage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.camelspace.com/product_detail.php?product=parachute#photos|title=Camelspace Products & Services|work=camelspace.com|accessdate=5 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150811143138/http://camelspace.com/product_detail.php?product=parachute#photos|archive-date=2015-08-11|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The 2012 festival saw a refreshed version of the former mainstage used at previous festivals. The mainstage currently used is a trailer that converts into a large stage and it is called 'Sam.'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/waikato-times/news/8210173/Hundreds-of-lights-shine-at-Parachute |title=Hundreds of lights shine at Parachute|work=Stuff|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref>
In the past the festival has had up to nine stages running at one time. Notable former stages include: * Debut Stage - In 2010 the Debut Stage was replaced and changed to The Apollo. * The Dome - In 2010 The Dome was demolished by Mystery Creek Events Centre. * Massive - This stage hosted mostly dance crews, R&B and hip-hop artists. Massive was integrated into the Palladium stage programme in 2012, and then returned on 2014. * The Hangar/White Elephant - This stage was the home to acoustic performances and was integrated into the Deluxe stage programme in 2012. * The Cage - This stage was run when the festival was hosted in Matamata.
Various other stages have appeared at festival in the past.
At the 2000 and 2001 Parachute Festivals, there was also a separate 'festival within a festival' dedicated to electronic and dance music in its various forms. This N'Dorphin Village was created by members of Dance Generation and featured continuous DJing and live electronica acts, along with urban dance culture elements such as break dancing performances and live Hip Hop.
